questions.question: Which of the following is the method of choice for the purification of highly polluted water ona large scale?
Which of the following is true regarding chlorination of water?

options.A: Orthotolidine test measures only combined chlorine
options.B: Chlorine acts best when the pH of water is around seven
options.C: It kills bacteria, viruses, spores and slime organisms
options.D: Hypochlorite ions are mainly responsible for its disinfectant activity

questions.explanation: Chlorine acts best when the pH of water is around seven because of the predominance of thehypochlorous acid. Most water sources have a pH around 6.5-7, making chlorination an effectiveform of disinfection.Option A: Orthotolidine test measures both free and combined chlorine in water.Option C: Chlorination kills pathogenic bacteria, but has no effect on spores and certain viruses.Option D: The disinfecting action of chlorine is mainly due to hypochlorous acid.

questions.question: You assign a male health worker at a sub-centre with the task of chlorinating public waterresources. What is the minimum concentration of free residual chlorine that should bemaintained for effective chlorination?

options.A: 0.5 mg/litre for a contact period of 1 hour
options.B: 0.5 mg/litre for a contact period of ½ hour
options.C: 0.8 mg/litre for a contact period of 1 hour
options.D: 0.8 mg/litre for a contact period of ½ hour

questions.explanation: The minimum recommended concentration of free residual chlorine for routine chlorination is 0.5mg/litre for a contact period of 1 hour.

questions.question: As an epidemiologist, you are investigating an outbreak of cholera. What is the minimum freeresidual chlorine level that should be maintained in pipelines to prevent further spread of the546outbreak?
questions.explanation: The minimum level of free residual chlorine to be maintained in pipelines following an outbreakof cholera is 0.5 mg/litre.After a disaster (such as a flood), the water bodies are contaminated with sewage and drainage.The mixing of faeces in drinking bodies increases the risk of numerous microbial infections. Theadvisable level of free residual chlorine in water bodies after a disaster is, therefore, higheri.e. 0.7-0.9 mg/litre.

questions.question: The municipal corporation in your area is performing routine chlorination of drinking watersupplies. Which of the following statements about chlorination is incorrect?

options.A: Free chlorine is released in water after breakpoint chlorination
options.B: Chlorine demand is the amount needed to kill spores, protozoal cysts and helminthic ova
options.C: 0.5 ppm of free chlorine must be present in water after the breakpoint has been reached
options.D: Contact period of 1 hour is necessary

questions.explanation: Chlorine demand is the amount of chlorine that is needed to kill bacteria, and to oxidize all theorganic matter and ammoniacal substances in the water. It is the difference between the amountof chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of aspecific period of contact (usually 1 hour) at a given temperature and pH of the water.5510.5 ppm (0.5 mg) of free chlorine must be present in water after the breakpoint has been reached.

questions.question: Which of the following tests identifies free and combined chlorine in water separately?
questions.explanation: Orthotolidine-arsenite test determines both free and combined chlorine in water separately.Orthotolidine test determines free and combined chlorine together.Chick Martin test and Garrod's test are used to test the efficacy of disinfectants.

questions.question: Which of the following compounds is predominantly responsible for the disinfecting propertyof bleaching powder?
questions.explanation: The disinfectant property of bleaching powder is predominantly due to the action of hypochlorousacid. It is 70-80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.Bleaching powder, also known as chlorinated lime (CaOCl2), has 33 per cent of chlorine in it.When chlorine is added to water, there is the formation of hydrochloric and hypochlorous acids.The hydrochloric acid is neutralized by the alkalinity of the water. The hypochlorous acid ionizesto form hydrogen ions and hypochlorite ions, as follows:H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCIHOCl → H + OC1

questions.question: 547A village health and sanitation team is planning to disinfect 100 wells. Which of the followingis the most cost-effective method in this scenario?
questions.explanation: Disinfection of wells using bleaching powder is the most widely used and cheapest method.

questions.question: An outbreak of viral hepatitis A has been reported in a village. On investigating, you find a contaminated well in the locality to be the source of the outbreak. Which of the following methods would you advise for chlorinating the well in this scenario?
questions.explanation: The double pot method is used for disinfecting wells by chlorination in emergencies like a hepatitis A outbreak in a village. The double pot method has an inner and outer pot, each with a hole in it and covered with a polyethylene foil. The inner pot is filled with bleaching powder and coarse sand. The double pot system is then lowered into a well. This device can work satisfactorily for 2 - 3 weeks in small wells containing about 4500 litres of water.

questions.question: What is the amount of bleaching powder required to disinfect 455 litres of water if the 4th,5th, and 6th cups of a Horrock's apparatus show distinct blue color?
questions.explanation: The dose of bleaching powder required is 8 grams.It is given by (n x 2) gms for 455 litres of water, where n is the number of the first cup that showsdistinct blue color. In this scenario, the dose of bleaching powder required to disinfect 455 litresof water is (4 x 2) = 8grams.

questions.question: Which of the following agents have residual germicidal effect when used for treatment ofwater?
questions.explanation: Chlorine has residual germicidal effect when used for treatment of water.UV radiation, ozone gas, iodine and potassium permanganate have good germicidal action but donot have residual germicidal effect.

questions.question: 549Which of the following properties of ozone makes it less suitable for the disinfection of wateron a large scale?

options.A: Ozone requires a long time period for action
options.D: It has no residual disinfectant action

questions.explanation: Ozone has no residual disinfectant action.Ozone gas can be used as a primary disinfectant of water in a large scale. Ozone disinfection isusually followed by biological filtration or granular activated carbon to prevent furthercontamination during distribution. Chlorine residual treatment is also done as ozone does notprovide for a residual disinfectant action.

questions.question: Which of the following is a lower-pressure membrane process for treatment of water?
questions.explanation: Microfiltration is a lower-pressure membrane process used for the treatment of water. Membrane processes are employed in the large-scale treatment of water. They are classified as high-pressure processes and lower-pressure processes. High-pressure processes include: Reverse osmosis - Rejects monovalent ions and organic molecules of molecular weight > 50 daltons. It is most commonly used for desalination of brackish water and seawater. The membrane pore size is < 0.002 μm. Nanofiltration - Allows monovalent ions such as sodium or potassium to pass but rejects a high proportion of divalent ions like calcium and magnesium and some higher molecular weight organics. The membrane pore size ranges from 0.001 to 0.01 μm. Lower-pressure processes include: Ultrafiltration - Rejects organic molecules of molecular weight > 800 daltons. The membrane pore size ranges from 0.002 to 0.003 μm. Microfiltration - Rejects colloidal and suspended material. It does not separate molecules and is usually used before reverse osmosis. The membrane pore size ranges from 0.01 to 12 μm.
